title: Water Cooled Parametric Mini Pump
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by Madox's Mini Centrifugal Pump, I created this one from the ground up using OpenSCAD (and my Geany text editor configuration). The big change is the introduction of water cooling. Without it, the motor gets fairly warm at higher flows. A small portion of the output is routed into the motor cavity and drains out the back via the printed hoses. The motor is sealed on both ends with some Oogoo orings to keep the water out of the motor internals. Healthy application of ABS glue ensures everything is sealed It uses a 7mm motor from a Syma S107 toy helicopter and is powered by a 3.7V lipo battery. I have driven it with PWM and have got excellent variable flow. It could definitely use some optimization but I am pleased with the first cut. Here is a video:
http://youtu.be/BDCUHT5uvGk

It is designed to be printed with 0 infill aside from top and bottom infill (set to 3 and 3).   
Note that extrusion width is one of the parameters in the .scad. Set this to your value to ensure proper sizing. Mine is 0.4mm. I used 0.15mm layers.  
Slic3r did a couple of odd things with the print, including not infilling the second layer of the Motor Cap, which made the top (3rd) layer very sparse. I will have to look into that more.

title: 3dfx Voodoo2 1000 fan shroud
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a fan shroud for a reference 3dfx Voodoo2 1000 video card. It should work on all vendor brands that use the reference 3dfx design that have three mounting holes on the edges of the card.

This shroud requires the use of four M3 15mm plastic standoffs and associated nuts and screws to attach it to the card, as well as a 10 or 15mm tall 60mm fan. Do not use metal standoffs on the card or you will damage/destroy the card.

To mount the shroud, install three of the M3 15mm standoffs on the Voodoo2 1000 video card, and install the fourth standoff near the SLI connector on the shroud itself pointing down. There is no mounting hole in this area, so this will be used as a foot support.

title: Corner or bracket for printer enclosures made with PVC tubes

description.text:
This corner will fit on 1/2" Schedule 40 PVC conduit from Home Depot or any other hardware store. To get a full enclosure, print 8 of them.

To do the enclosure faces, I decided to go for 5 panels made of "Reflectix small project rolls" panels (or multi layer reflective insulation) from Home Depot (24in x 10ft) which is enough for a CR10s enclosure. To hold the insulation on the frame, I used velcro in the corners and printed clips in between (see my other related Things to find those clips). The front panel is fixed with velcro only so that I can remove it easily. What is missing is an inside light, and you are good to go.

The holes in the 2 diagonal bracings are there to link two diagonally opposed corners with a wire to increase structure rigidity if needed. The through holes within the 3 branches are to fix the PVC tube within the bracket if needed (use a drill to drill the tube and use a wire or something to go through the bracket and PVC tube).

This is probably the cheapest and easiest-to-make enclosure. 3x of PVC tube cost 6$, one roll of reflective insulation 10$, 5ft of velcro 7$ and some wire for 3$ make a total of 26$ without filament.

Printer:

CR10s

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

15% grid or lines

Notes:

Any better resolution will work as well. Don't print with ABS or any material experiencing shrinkage. The fit is tight to the PVC enclosure to ensure proper stability.

I printed at 60mm/s for inner wall and infill, 30mm/s for outer wall to get a smooth finish. 4 bottom and upper layers but 3 would work as well.

No support needed! I made sure that all angles are 60° max. So any good printer with a fan will have no problem printing up to 60° overhang angles without problem.

Printed with eSun PLA+ light gray 225°C, bed 30°C, fan 100%.

Designed with Onshape

Ref: 2671352

I wanted the clip-on camera mount from sb43201, but needed the spacing from the clip-on to be 3mm which is the size of the arms from the pi camera v2 by luc358.

Also, you'll find a new camera back that has 20mm diameter cutouts so that you can attach heatsinks (I used 14mm x 14mm ones off of Amazon) to help dissipate some of the heat those lights generate.
Remixed using Tinkercad just to remove extra material so the spacing is 3mm instead of 2mm for the clip. Then, holed out a 20mm cutout for the heatsinks. Easy peasy.

I designed this unit to accept 4 18650 Li-Ion Cells, 2 in series, 2 in parallel, for the purpose of powering a night-light. The cable end is designed to be epoxied into place, the other end clips on and off (may require a screwdriver to pop off). This unit is designed and tested/proven to withstand popping open under extreme conditions, as I use it strapped as shown to my mountain bike frame - I downhill at night with this thing on the (in)famous north shore mountains of Vancouver, British Columbia. Vancouver is also a temperate rain-forest, so this unit also withstands a substantial amount of rain and mud.

I use Orbtronic Protected Cells (https://www.orbtronic.com/18650-protected-battery-3500mah-lithium-ion), which are longer (68.9 mm) than unprotected cells.

description.text:
Customizable lock core hand holder. This was strongly influenced by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1386781 with the following improvements

  1. Optional cutaway for cut away locks (note if yours is cutaway on the other side just mirror the part in your slicer.
  2. Extra room in the back to allow the unlocked cylinder to rotate freely when pushed all the way into the holder.
  3. Set screw is now 6-32x1/4" (a plus or a minus), which is the most common size "coarse" computer screw, so you should be able to find one around your house or at a computer shop. Also the nut is now optional, if you choose not to print the nut then you can either tap 6-32 threads or just have the screw self tap (ABS recommended in this case).
  4. Holder now has parallel long sides, so you can place it in a vice more easily. The original oval shape an option as well.

title: Guitar Hero Whammy Bar Replacement Part

description.text: This is a replacement part for a broken whammy bar for a Wii Guitar Hero guitar. A little nib broke off causing the whammy bar to not spring back.

I designed the part in CATIA V6. It came out pretty well, but I had to file the interior of the side pegs quite a bit to get it to fit. I suspect I should have increased the diameters of both by 05.mm-1.0mm. I did make one small modification to the original design (besides making the holes too small). I added fillets to the edges of the nib that broke off originally. Hopefully this will add enough strength to keep it from happening again.
I'm not sure what 3d printer I used, but it looks expensive (I'll try to find out wich model it is). I'm participating in a workshop and we were given one chance to make any part we wanted, so I wanted to make a part that I don't think I can print on my Replicator.

comments.text: This looks like a great fix although in my case it's a Rock Band guitar that needs a new whammy bar mount.

title: Animated Picture Frame, Motorized Edition
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Well not exactly a "picture frame", but... Icons march around the frame calling attention to the picture of your choice. Video of the prototype is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aXC7k8weS-M&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA. When it comes to the icons, you can design and print your own, or use light weight material such as heavy construction paper, balsa wood, stickers on cardboard, etc., and glue them to the pins. For the prototype, my wife wanted "Lora & Greg & Lora", so I printed the letters in PLA and glued each to the pins using thick cyanoacrylate and accelerator (hot glue should also work, just not too hot). Designed using Sketchup 8 and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42.

Study "Assembly.skp". I used "6VDC 45 RPM Pinky Finger Sized Gear Motor 1" Long x 15/32" x 3/8"" from either amazon.com or directly from http://sciplus.com/p/MICROMOTOR_47952 to move the track. Other sources are available, I've not tested them though. I also used a coaxial power jack (Radio Shack part number 274-1583) and a 1.5vdc power supply (Radio Shack part number 273-315). You can skip the coaxial power jack and solder the power supply directly to the motor if desired. Print "TopInside.stl". Using a glue stick, double sided tape, etc., attach your photo onto the smooth surface side of "TopInside.stl". Then using a very sharp razor knife or blade, trim the photo to follow exactly the outside edge of "TopInside.stl" making sure no part of the photo extends beyond the surface of "TopInside.stl". Print "Chain.stl". Snap chains end to end making sure the pin holding cups are on the same side. Carefully work the chain to loosen all links. This may take awhile. All links must move freely. Print "Track.stl". Print "MotorMount.stl". Install motor into motor mount, solder your power supply or coaxial power jack to the motor, then press the assembly onto "Track.stl". Note the orientation as it will only fit one way. Place "Gear.stl" inside "Chain.stl", carefully lowering the two into "Track.stl", then press "Gear.stl" onto the motor shaft making sure the flats align. Also make sure the pin cups on "Chain.stl" are facing up. Print as many of "Pin.stl" that you will require. Carefully sand the base of each pin until if fits snuggly inside the pin cup in "Chain.stl". Repeat with the remaining pins as required in the location you choose. You can glue the pins in the pin cup, but I don't recommend it for two reasons; first, grandkids, if they pick up the frame in the wrong manner the pins will release from the pin cups with little or no damage, and second, after the icons are glued onto the pins, it is difficult if not impossible to remove "FrontOutside.stl" since the icons are in the way (depending on the size of the icons). Press "TopInside.stl" onto "Track.stl", noting the orientation of the gear guide. Print "TopOutside.stl", then press it onto "Track.stl". Print "Back.stl", then press it onto "Track.stl". Glue icons onto the pins. I positioned my pins on the chain first. Then to glue a letter to a pin, I placed a small (and I mean small) dot of thick cyanoacrylate (thick cyanoacrylate is available at most model hobby shops) on the pin tip, sprayed the back side of the letter with accelerator, then positioned the letter on the pin. The cyanoacrylate sets within 5 seconds.

So I had a odd request for a 3D model of the "Face On Mars" hill. So I scoured the net for some actual hight data of this hill. I say hill because it is only 1.5 miles wide. There is a great hight data of Mars but not in a high enough resolution for this little hill.

All I could find is this hi-res image taken with the HiRISE camera on the MRO and a short animation made by ESA using the HRSC.

So I took what I had and freehand modeled my own the best I could. I hate to toot my own horn but my 3D model looks better then the one done by the ESA back in 2006.

I made my own short animation with this mode. It can be seen here. Enjoy!

title: DJI Spark/Mavic Mobile Command Center
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A DJI Spark/Mavic RC adapter to hold larger devices or Tablets at the top of the RC. Plus the added feature to mount the whole thing on a camera tripod or a camera shoulder strap, for a hand free feel.

BUILD & USE AT YOUR OWN RISK. I am not responsible for any damage to personal property that may happen while using this model.

Please Respect the CC Licence These are not to be built and sold for personal gain. Greed is humanities greatest weakness.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Resolution:

.1-.3 mm

Infill:

25% or more

Notes:

-I tried to build this model so it fits at all resolutions printed. The higher the res .001 the tighter the fit and the stronger the model.

-Build at the settings you feel comfortable with.

-This model is assembled around the RC using 4 screws. You'll have to remove 2 of them to get the RC out of the model to fold up for storage.

-There is only 2 cradles to print. The device cradle and the 2 smaller top hooks will fit smartphones to an iPad mini. And the Tablet version will fit iPad mini to a full-sized iPad.

-Device and Tablet Top Hooks: They may have to be sanded on the shaft a bit to slide better in the cradle. You can rotate it and print it vertically to reduce supports too. I just did it like this for strength. I have printed both ways and it seems to be strong.

-Instructions are below. The final 5 images above goes with the instructions.

Elastic Peg's

Carefully tap out the two 1/4" holes on the back of the cradle to match the two random screws/bolts you have. They should protrude out about a 1/4" for the elastic to wrap around.

Metal Thread Adapters

Carefully tap out the 5 holes that have a small collar on the cradle and grip support. 2 are on the cradle and 3 are on the grip support. Use a 3/8" 16-unc thread tap. Install the 3/8-1/4 adapters into the newly tapped holes.

RC Padding & Device Grip

Add some foam tape on the edge of the cradle that sits over the RC. I purposely put this space in here to add the foam tape. This is to give some cushion on the RC to avoid damage to it.
If you find your device slides side to side in the cradle then add some foam tape in it for grip on your device. The rubber case on my phone works good enough, so I didn't have to add the foam tape for grip.

My Thoughts

This is the first drone I have owned. When I first got it and used it with the RC (remote control) I said "This is all wrong".
The screen under the controls just felt backwards to me. I don't have x-ray vision to see through my hands. My phone also just barely fit after I removed the case. And to top it off, I couldn't plug the otg cable in.
When I was learning how to use the Spark and the hand gestures, I found myself looking for a place to set the RC down. And when I would try to do a slow movement video I would stabilize my RC on my knee.
So I set out to fix all this in one shot. When you fly a ship, you have a command center. And that is what I built.

As I modeled this I had to keep four things in mind. Make it strong enough to support a heavy device, make it universal for as many devices as possible, make it portable, and make it easy to print with minimal supports. So pretty much K.I.S.S (Keep It Simple Stupid)

I decided to not make the device cradle pivot. This makes it easier to print and ensures strength. It currently sits at a 45deg angle from the RC, what seems to be just right. I have it in a position so the antennas can still point up or forwards.
The bolt pegs for the elastic was more for safety to avoid model breaking and dropping a device. But be sure to check your elastic!

The 3 piece design allows for easy printing with minimal supports. It gives the option to change out between the device cradle and tablet cradle quickly. And it can be easily tore down to fit into a small bag. If a part breaks or if the model changes at all you wont have to reprint the whole thing.

I didn't want all the weight to be on grip plate in the RC arms causing damage to the RC. So I put a lip on the cradle that rests just above the top of the RC. This is the lip you put some foam padding on to protect the RC. With this, the weight is now distributed in a twist fashion between the top of the RC and the fold out arms. But when it is mounted to the tripod all the weight is on the model itself and off the RC. This is why I recommend the tripod for the tablet version.

This has got to be my best accessory for my Spark. I use it with my Nexus 6 on and off the tripod, and enjoy it. Hope you guys like it.

title: Linear Bearing Holder Bracket - 2 sizes, 4 configurations

description.text:
My friend asked me to print him some LM8UU bearing blocks. I couldn't find anything that I liked, and was easy to print without any support required, so designed this one.

The design is done so as to need no support, but still provide a great channel for the cable tie to loop through.

I have designed two types for each size. An end mount and a side mount.

Sizes available are for:
LM8UU
LM10UU
PLEASE CHOOSE THE RIGHT SIZE BEFORE PRINTING!
If you would like any other sizes, please let me know in the comments below.

Prusa

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I print these with no support and at least 3 or 4 outer layers. I also tried printing at 100% infill and had good success.

Design should require no clean-up, provided your printer is dialled in or calibrated properly. I added 0.2mm to the diameter and length of the clearance pocket for the bearing. This should take care of any shrinkage of the plastic during printing

remixed_from.author: enif
remixed_from.title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

description.text:
About 200mm in height, 41mm depth.
The ampersand is printed in PLA
The LED bulbs is printed in Colorfabb nGen Clear
Battery box is PETG with OA:s recommended layer height of 0.25mm

LED (wharm white): https://www.kjell.com/se/sortiment/el-verktyg/elektronik/optokomponenter/lysdioder/lysdiod-5-mm-varmvit-p90729

I found the sweet spot for the LEDs at about 5mA, that is 1kOhm at 5 volts.
Original spec: 20mA

The threads in PLA works quite well, I cleared them with a thread tool just because.

Since I wanted the bulbs to be as clear as possible they got printed with a 0.6mm nozzle and the flow at about 110-120% so the threads became a bit "undefined", I sharpened them the classic, mechanical way with a thread tool M10x1.5

Hot melt to secure the LEDS, wiring and USB female at the battery box

Source files included

title: USB Type C 3.1 Male to Micro USB Female Adapter Keychain Holder

description.text:
Nowdays living in transition period from micro USB (2.0) to USB Type C ( 3.0, 3.1) you can find Micro USB cable pretty much anywhere, not like the USB Type C. Hence this adapter holder comes in favor. It is almost anecessity to have one adapter with you all the time in case of emergency to charge your gadgets/tools from micro USB.

It has been designed about a year ago and does the job just perfect. Sorry for the "not fresly printed" item pictures as it is after about 1 year use.

Printed in PLA and its desing is to be durable enough in pretty much any material printed.

Its design does not allow it to fall out as the keychain stops it and pushes it back if it tries to slide off. Hasn't dropped out a single time from a start of using day to day basis.

Adapter itself:
https://www.gearbest.com/iphone-cables-adapters/pp_288342.html

For more join fresh new Facebook group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/3DPrintingWorld/

Why spend $6 for a new bottle when you can use your own Brita filter to refill your 5 gallon water cooler bottle? When I tried to do this without a support collar I would have to hold the filter the whole time since the diameter of the bottom of the filter and the top of the bottle are close to the same (52 and 55mm). Just place the collar on the bottle about 1/3 of the way and the filter system on top 2/3. This works perfectly with no leakage. Enjoy!
I designed this tube in Sketchup after measuring the top of the bottle and bottom of the filter.

title: Part Cooling Nozzle for Anycubic Kossel

description.text:
UPDATE 2018-01-11: Added _RevA. Came across the problem that the hotend had difficulties reaching and keeping very high temperatures as the original nozzle seems to cool the hotend as well. Probably related to the comment by friggy?
Changed the nozzle to blow more downward and also increased clearance to the hotend to make for an easier fit.

Part cooling nozzle for stock radial fan on Anycubic Kossel. I have the Linear Plus version, but assume all use the same effector, so should fit all Anycubic Kossels.

It is a bit of a monstrosity compared to the other very elegant cooling nozzle designs out there, but this was done in order to increase the cross sections for air flow. This way we get the most out of the stock radial fan.

The nozzle really helps a lot when printing PLA at high temperatures for best layer adhesion.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print in ABS for heat resistance. The slopes will print just fine, turn off supports.

Wish your gamer a happy birthday in a Minecraft inspired font!  
Two files are included, one with and one without little support legs to stick into a cake.

Imported the font into Blender and extruded to make the text.  The supporting structure was added in Tinkercad.  
Printed with a Ultimaker with 0.2 mm layer thickness, 0.8 mm wall thickness, 10% fill at 50 mm/s.  Top and bottom thickness is set to 2 mm (to ensure the faces are completely filled).  Scaled up to 14 cm width in the picture.

These buckets are designed to complement and fit in the Tactix organiser trays, often available at Bunnings. They are designed with the following features:

  • Compatible with the existing orange buckets (you can mix and match in the same tray)
  • Pourable. The two compartments in each bucket have a diagonal overhang on an inside corner which holds back the parts while you pour parts out of the other compartment. This works even better if you hold your thumb above the diagonal overhang.
  • Easy to access parts. Compartments are just big enough to still fit big fat thumbs and fingers into (like mine) to scoop out small parts. The bottom is also filleted on the pouring edge for this purpose.
  • Stackable. The feet lock into the tops of other printed buckets (this is also how the half height buckets sit in the tray)
  • Easy to print. A raft or support will be needed for the main flat area around the legs, but everything else can be printed without support, and relatively quickly.
  • Label guides, to consistently place labels made from standard 12mm tape (guides are 24mm apart)

The trays come in two sizes, a large one sold separately, and a set of 3 smaller ones in a carrier. These trays are great for small parts, as the buckets are indexed into place, the lid has insets to stop parts cross-pollinating during transport, and the buckets can be removed for easy access to the parts (you can pour them out).

The largest bucket that comes with the trays is 50x50mm though, which is unnecessarily large when dealing with tiny electronic components or really small screws. The buckets provided here are designed to slot in the same way as the orange Tactix ones that come with the trays, but allow you to split it up even further.

The design document for this is publicly available on Onshape here: Tactix Organiser Buckets

Anyone can view public Onshape documents without an account, but you'll need a free account to modify the design.

Credit for the files I edited to make this http://3dupndown.com/content/?page=&pcode=cont_view_new&mtype=au&idx=6916&chargeType=

Check out my video -> https://youtu.be/WyuVjLcOJ6g

Just had my local public library use the 3D printer donated by my colleague Friends of the Library to print up a copy of this Mount Vernon Bastille Key. title: Steam Controller Shoulder / Bumper / Trigger Mechanism

description.text:
Steam Controller missing 3d model: bumper mechanism, in case you break yours.

Update: this part has been through more than 20 hours of thorough testing and beating in a series of games. I consider it a success. Even its springiness did not decrease. It does not get stuck. I will likely be updating in the future with instructions on how to tune the part.

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You have to print it in polycarbonate. It's the only plastic both rigid and strong enough to withstand the mechanical needs of that part. PLA is rigid but is not strong. Nylon is strong but it is not rigid. And you have to print in high temperatures (at least 290°C) so the layers get good adherence (essencial to such a tiny part with holes).

In my printer I also use horizontal size expansion of -0.08mm to adjust for spread of molten filament.

Cleaning up and holing up

After printing it up and carefully removing the supports (polycarbonate is a tough material, so you have to be careful to not break the part when removing the supports), sand its surface a little then proceed to enlarge/melt the two little 'flap' holes. The original part has one metal rod connecting the holes between these flaps and a spring that connects to the round hole in the middle of the part. In both cases, I suggest that you get a heat gun, heat these metal parts and use them on the print - the rod to adjust the holes, the spring to make it stick in a diagonal angle to the flat face.

Why don't I design these holes in the right size? I did, actually. But FDM 3d printing has a know problem with small holes. And in this case the hole is very close to a thin vertical column of plastic, where the FDM anisotropy gets its worst. So if you melt around the hole, its strength gets a lot better. Don't forget to check if the metal rod can slide between the two holes but also has some friction - you'll need it to assemble and disassemble this part.

Tough design. Might be improved.

That was a hell of a struggle to get this working. I had to change lots of minuscule details for each iteration. Wasted a lot of plastic, took four days of continuous experimentation to finish. If you can deal with FreeCAD, the file is completely modifiable, and the license is permissive, so I would be delighted if you can improve the design - maybe you can make the trigger "click"?

Also, notice that the steam controller 3d models file by Valve lacks not one, but two parts. The other part is the one that connects to this one via the metal rod. I did not model that because mine did not break. I can not afford spending more time on it. But if you can, I would be very grateful. Everyone would.

Context and Explanation

The Steam Controller from Valve is a revolutionary biometric device. It is shaped like a gamepad but with two programmable trackpads on it, and it also has a stick and an internal gyroscope that allows for precise movement in rotation X, Y and Z axes. And it does not stop there: Valve even published the entire 3D model of the device so that you can easily make your own 3D printed mods and fix your device in case it breaks.

The entire 3D model, I said?

Not really. For some mysterious reason, the most breakable part of the entire device, the trigger/bumper mechanism below these buttons, is missing from their files. And guess what - my controller broke exactly there, and as I live in a 3rd world country where this device costs three times more than in the US and we earn 5 times less, I would NOT buy a whole other device just for that broken button.

So, I did exactly what I had to do, I disassembled the controller, took a few photos of the broken part and its unbroken mirrored part, opened the open-source solid modeller freecad, modelled the part using caliper measurements and a reference photo, and... failed horribly. Printing in common plastics such as PLA, ABS and even nylon would make the part very breakable and too soft.

I resorted to about 22 iterations of modelling, exporting to Cura, printing in polycarbonate (the only material fit for this purpose, it seems) at 290°C (554°F), assembling it in place of the defective part, testing it, until I finally got some functional results, including the tactitle feedback of the bumper.

The part is not perfect by any means. Depending on how you assemble it on the controller, it might not 'click' or even press the bumper button. You might have to heat and bend it a little if so desired, it's usually at a very particular angle that it works, although I did my best to work out of the printer. Also, the trigger does not yet give a 'clicked' feedback, although it works perfectly. I did my best so that the spring action is ok and the buttons do not get stuck firing.

comments.text: Ive broken 10+ controllers on the LB button, from various time frames, months to weeks to days. The button implementation there is severely flawed and I'm sick of sending in the controller for replacements and waiting weeks to get back to playing Rocket League. I resorted to having multiple controllers on hand instead. I'm going to try this out and see what will happen. Hopefully we can improve on the implementation and stop breaking controllers
comments.author: emsid

comments.text: I hope you are successful, I don't think there's much else to do to get it perfect, I think that a microscopic dent somewhere in the part would create the 'clicking' effect for the trigger button. Please let me know of your conclusions, I will probably get back to the design and change it accordingly.
comments.author: emsid

comments.text: How about printing in ABS ?
comments.author: alia5

comments.text: Doesn't work because ABS is too soft, the spring effect needed for the little flap is too weak. Also, in ABS the anisotropic effect is even worse than in PLA - which means, the low adherence of layers cause the vertical resistance to pull to be even weaker, so the hold and dents of the tabs would easily break.

description.text:
This GOTEK mount moves the screen and replicates the 2 buttons to the top of the Atari ST.

This also relocates the 9-Pin DSUB ports to the rear of the machine for easier access.

Use 2x M3x8mm bolts to screw the retainer to the rear of the control bezel.

This bar holds the 2x 6mm tactile switches in place along with the screen.

I cut the required hole in the top vents with a dremel and used 2-part Epoxy to fix the bezel.

For the Ports i used 2x Male and 2x Female 9pin dsub ports soldered pin to pin with ribbon cable.

Whwn cutting the ST casing be careful with the cleanup / deburring as the vents will be quite fragile once you cut through them.

Cleanup will be required as the casing (ABS ??) tends to fluff up after using the dremel.

For the floppy case cutting i simply "squared off" the rear of the ST floppy port and took approx 10x10mm rom the bottom left as you look at it to accomodate the left hand button.

I would recommend printing the main frame and assembling into the ST bare to get a good idea of where to cut 1st.

I applied the Epoxy carefully to the back of the bezel on the vertical faces only as the top flange is there to cover any imperfections.

description.text: You can fit in two pen/ pencils on this weird looking pen stand. Its inspired from a temple design, thats why it has "Fractal Enlightenment" inscribed on it. Intended for personal printing, it has my face at the back of it (captured using MS Kinect), feel free to remove it.

I was receiving a lot of parts from all of my projects, but I was still having trouble finding parts I knew I had. So I made this. It is great for storing nuts, screws, washers, standoffs and bolts, from size m2 to m5. It is great for your racing drone hobby, general RC hobby, or your 3d printing hobby.

Both parts print flat on you printbed, which should be at least 200x150mm. Both parts come with tabs to make sure that the parts stay stuck to the print bed. They should be cut off afterwards.

The hinge is made by screwing m2 bolts into the base though the holes in the lid. The lid will snap into place because of the tabs on the front of the box.
Gear Test

This is a remix of sirusdv's excellent design.

I have changed it to allow it to fit a monitor which has 45mm long vertical slot at the rear.

I also moved the mount 20mm further forward. This puts the screen nearer to you and also gives the transmitter antenna better 'view' of the craft.

You need a 1/4-20 UNC A2 countersunk screw (3/8" - 1/2" long) to secure the monitor to the mount.

I also added an optional neck strap balancer (because the original mount is too far away when the monitor is attached).
For the neck strap balancer, you need 2 x 15mm M3 screws and nuts.

This will probably fit the FS-i6X (but I'm not sure).
It's a support for a curtain rod.

This is a two-piece ceiling hook assembly. Mount the anchor with a screw through the center hole, and then push on the hook, and twist 90 degrees to lock it into place. A small line on the anchor shows which way the hook will point.  
This hook was designed for use with a drywall/plaster anchor, although you could also screw it directly to a joist. Or anything else, really. The hole and cavities are sized for a No.8-12 screw, but should fit larger screws as well.  
Toleranced for a Replicator 2. See print instructions for details. The hook_stronger variant is thicker. Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360, with some manipulation in Autodesk meshmixer.

I print the hook on its side, so that the outer shell layers run around the hook. This results in a much stronger part than printing vertically, because of the thin sections. For the anchor I print with the small rim on the bed. This avoids warping on the mating surfaces.  
I print these at .2mm / 3 shells / 25% infill, for strength. Total print time for both parts is about an hour.  
I use makerware support for both pieces, and a raft for the hook. Make sure to be thorough getting the support out of the inside of the hook base (I use a small wood chisel, works great). Since it is a ceiling hook, it is far enough away that you cannot see the details, so I don't bother with any sanding/etc.  
The tolerance is tuned for a Makerbot Replicator 2. Initially the parts will not fit (do not try to force them, or the anchor will get stuck!). Screw the anchor down to a piece of scrap wood, and push the hook up and down a few times until it slides smoothly. Then do the same until you can just barely twist it into place (careful not to snap the hook).   
The rim on the base is there to leave space for a drywall/plaster anchor, and so should end up flush with the ceiling. Screw it on, twist on the hook, and you are ready to hang something.  
For the stronger variant, I have included a small sizing print, if you want to check that the hook will be big enough for your purpose. It is just a slice of the hook, prints in a few minutes.  
No idea how much weight it can support, but the "stronger" variant is currently holding up 14 globe bulbs hanging over my dining room table.

Here is my night vision scope attachment. It uses a CCD bullet cam and a 5 inch LCD. Total cost should be less then 100 dollars without the illumination. I am still working out my illumination. I purchased 850nm light with 67mm objective lens. The light is super bright but the tube is 30mm and the only adjustable mount I was able to find is lacking. I would recommend trying a T20 ir light because it has a 1" tube.

description.text: This is a parametric Fusion 360 model which can be used to create custom-sized brackets for holding circular pots and attach to the edge of a board or other material. Generally, only the PotDiameter and BoardThickness parameters will need to be adjusted, though several other attributes of the model have been parametrized as well.

(Not really recommended for use unless you are prepared to modify the design.) A box for an ethermega arduino with a prototype shield connected and room to add things like servo connectors and Oled display. The PCB boards and top and bottom of case are held in by slots that they slide into and the end plates are held on by built-in clips. No screws required. There is lots of ventilation holes that also make it easy to cut out access holes.
Problems/deficits:
The spacing for the PCBs wasn't quite right and needed a bit of filing. The end-plates don't have cutouts for Ethernet, USB or power, but you could add those to the openscad files if you wanted. The clips are a bit fragile and easily snap off (but superglue back on nice and strongly) and the sides of the case don't have matching slots for the clips. (I made them manually). I'd make the clips differently next time.

Files are a mixture of Sketchup and Openscad because I got sick of Sketchup and learned Openscad halfway thru the project. The slicing of the sides and top took a long time, probably because of all the little holes. I'd use slots next time.
It was printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2.

remixed_from.author: jamisonhodges
remixed_from.title: Boscam RX-LCD5802 FPV Monitor Mount for Spektrum DX6 Transmitter

description.text:
This is for Spektrum DX6, DX7 and DX8 (and other Spektrum models with the same antenna).
It clamps onto the 2 grooves around the antenna which provides an extremely strong and stable attachment.

The monitor should have the 45mm long slot at the rear, which the mount slides into.

Parts needed:

  • 1/4-20 UNC A2 countersunk screw (3/8" - 1/2" long) to secure the monitor to the mount.
  • 2 x 20mm M3 screws and 2 nuts. (If you use longer screws, you will need to drill the hole deeper.)

You can print both pieces together if you use the bigger .stl file (118kb).
(The 2 pieces are separated by a 0.5mm gap)

I added an optional neck strap balancer (because the original mount is too far away when the FPV monitor is attached).
For the neck strap balancer, you need 2 x 15mm M3 screws and nuts.

No

Infill:

40%

description.text: Perhaps youâ€™re a gardener and have seen these little butterflies (Cabbage Moth / Cabbage Butterfly Plutella xylostella, Pieris rapae) that lay eggs on cabbage, then the caterpillars devour your vegetables. This is a little tool for drilling holes at right angles to things, primarily walls. However, this guide also has a dust catcher. The slot in the guide tube allows the dust to fall out of the drill flutes into the catcher. With this tool you can put in a drywall anchor above your couch without having to move it or make a huge mess.  
There are two slots on the edges, those are crosshairs you can use to line up the center of the tube (see photos). The "ledge" for your finger and the catcher should both be bigger, and if your print warps, some of the dust may still escape down the wall. But most of it will end up in the bucket.   
The hole is sized for a 1/4" bit. The part was designed in Autodesk Fusion 360, and I have included several CAD formats if you want to edit it for different sizes. I suppose you could also try scaling.
Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2 at Low quality, for fastest print. No support needed if printed with the tube vertical.

comments.text: This is a great candidate for something to model in OpenSCAD, since you could have the drill bit hole be a parameter.....

This is a remix of the first gauntlet that I designed to use with the Cyborg Beast. I found that I needed to reinforce version 1 when I scaled the print down to a smaller size. The velcro also put a lot of downward stress on the part so I changed the velcro slots to be inline with the vertical walls of the gauntlet. I am hoping this will help with stress on this section. This should also make the gauntlet a little less likely to "catch" on things. Karuna was interested in putting his shirt sleeve down over the gauntlet, so the vertical slots should help here as well. I also thinned the cable tensioner a bit to it has a lower profile for the same reason.

title: FLSun delta part cooling adapter for centrifugal fan

description.text:
My 2017 FLSun delta came with a rather anemic centrifugal fan for the parts cooler. There are other adapters around (like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2369318 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477073), but they all use axial fans. I felt like a centrifugal fan was the better approach, so I designed yet another fan shroud myself.

This was designed for the 2017 "New effector", using a 4020 centrifugal blower:

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Blower-cooling-Fan-40mmx40mmx20mm-DC-12V-2-Pin-Brushless-Cooling-Cooler-Centrifugal-Blower-Fan-4020/32828068985.html

However, I think most (if not all) 4020 blowers will work. Greatly reduces warping and sagging, but I have noticed a slight increase of rippling - possibly due to the added inertia. Does not collide with the delta arms on my "large linear" printer.

Combines very well with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2251745

Printer:

FLSun Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use a brim. Only add supports touching the buildplate. Enabling "Using support interface" will make the horizontal overhangs look better, but they will be out-of-sight when installed on the printer.

• Attach blower to adapter using 2 M3 bolts and 2 M3 nuts
  • Remove old centrifugal blower
  • Install the adapter into the slot. It should slide all the way down, but it might require some convincing to fit inside the hole in the base of the effector. Make sure that it sits flush with the bottom effector.
  • Connect the new blower. Observe the polarity (On my printer, the wires of the original fan had a counter-intuitive color coding, with red as ground, so beware)
Designed in OpenSCAD. I attached the source - which is probably not as clean as it could be. I don't know much about fluid dynamics, so the design of the duct may not be ideal.

author: pienjo

title: RepRap Discount Smart Controller LCD Case

description.text:
Edit - 12/21/2017, I modified Banholm's Y tensioner and added a ball mount for the LCD. Now I have a centralized location to keep my LCD "if I want". I may also print a few bolt on mounts to mount randomly inside the enclosure just to show off, lol.

This is my LCD case, though this version has some minor improvements to the one pictured as this case is part of a larger (currently incomplete) project for my Octoprint and other boards. That said, I'll only release the STL files and not the OpenSCAD files. When my Stack Pack project is complete, I will link these things to that project.

Improvements I've made for this release are a slightly longer SHTF button for better reach to the EMERGENCY SHUTOFF button, as well as a thru hole to screw in an M3 for more precise reach to the same button if the user deems that needed. I've made the mounting ball a separate piece that can be bolted to anything, or even several can be printed for users to have multiple mounting locations.

Mounting hardware is M4 screws of at least 10mm long if being attached to something that is 5mm thick. If thicker surfaces will be mounted to, user must select appropriate length fasteners. Also included is my stack pack lid for the case that will go under the LCD.

For the ball I suggest a higher infill, maybe 60%+ to keep ball from imploding or wearing out prematurely.

I made this thing so I could get my Canon EOS camera into prime focus on my dinky little telescope. The original focuser body was too long, so I made a shorter version that the original focuser tube and gears could fit into. I also used an adapter for the camera that I got from the thingiverse to connect the camera to the focuser tube. BTW, the diameter of the focuser tube is quite odd. Its Outer Diameter is 32 mm which is about 1.25" but that doesn't mean it takes a 1.25" lens. (Its inner diameter would have to be 32mm for that) so it doesn't match the 1.25" or 2" lens-mount standards on most telescopes. It just so happens that the EOS camera adapter I used slotted perfectly onto it. (See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10829 for info)

Files are Openscad and quite parametisable though you need to check carefully if you change any parameter values that it all still hangs together. To find out what each parameter does, you'll have to read the code, sorry.
The whitish cap that holds the focus knob and pinion gear on is made from 'plastimake' which is a low-temperature thermoplastic (uses hot water!) so you'll need to design one for yourself, unless I get around to it.
Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2.

Get rid of the annoying fruit flies (Drosophila). Well, it is a war you probably cannot win completely, but you can significantly reduce their numbers.
1) get a suitable glass or cup - so you can see inside.
2) measure the rim diameter and scale the print to fit your glass. If you print slightly big, you can easily fix it binding a tape around the glass rim.
3) drill cca 1-1.5 mm holes to the inner cones. Make lot of holes, so that the flies can smell the lemon. See the pictures - I have cca 6 holes per cone and it worked fine. Also drill a hole at the tip of the cones if it prints too tiny. Too big - they will find a way out. Too small - they will stay outside...
4) take a squeezed lemon, put it in the glass, close it with the trap and see the flies coming in.
5) make sure to empty the glass before the lemon gets mildew or is rotten. It is clever to open the trap outside your living quarters :-)
6) use lemon or other fruit that is loved by the flies. I have tried a lemon concetrate juice and the flies ignored it...

A neat little tool bin i put together quickly in TinkerCad. I based the bracket off of bradk2012's awesome little tool holder which i also printed out to hang on my Replicator. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30923 I just wanted something to hold the rest of the misc tools that wouldnt fit in the cup. You can easily adjust the depth if you want to in Cura or Makerware, i have it built at 3" deep to hold things like picks and files and other misc tidbits.

I printed the bracket with pretty much default settings, if you want to make it stronger to support more weight increase the infill percentage, you could even make it solid if you wanted.  
The bin i printed with a raft but no support and the Replicator was able to bridge the bottom without any trouble, maybe a very slight sag inward but who is ever going to notice it!

title: Cocktail Shot Layering Tool - The White One

description.text:
Like a lot of people, I like shots - especially the layered ones. There's nothing quite like a squashed frog :)
However, using the old 'pour the second drink off a spoon' trick always seemed to mix them down one side etc. A couple of years ago I came up with an idea for a tool that would solve that. After buying the bits (and losing a couple of them) the idea fell by the wayside and didn't get made.

I revisited this recently, and after learning a little bit more about 3D modelling, came up with this little beauty...... The White One. So called because of the colour - the reason will become obvious with my next model ;-)

Sit it in the glass, pour your first drink in up to the platform level through the larger side at the top.
Pour your second drink in the smaller side, which will come out on the platform and layer nicely.
Remove carefully (so as not to destroy your hard work), savour visually, then quaff.

Obviously printing at different heights will accommodate different sized glasses (though this one fits most of my different ones) and printing a couple at different heights would allow for 3-drink mixes.

Have fun! (Responsibly!)

(Sorry about the bad pictures and rough print - it was very late when printed fast, and I took the pictures in a bit of a hurry today, hence why I also disturbed the layer on the last image.)

print_settings.Notes:: You need to have good support settings and a well-tuned printer.  This is print will not tolerate sloppiness.

description.text:
I really wanted a scroll for the O'Cello so I found this wonderful violin print designed by bchan based on a Stradivarius and scaled it up to use as a base model to design and build the scroll. https://pinshape.com/items/24608-3d-printed-violin Also, since there were no major changes, if you have already printed an O'cello, you can easily swap to this design as well.

First I had to make them mate up. I redesigned the top of the neck and the bottom of the scroll. I wanted a joint that had a mechanical fit and I also wanted to integrate the through holes for the strings.

This all took a fair bit of work to design, but the real challenge was to generate an FDM printable scroll. I tried a couple of orientations and supports systems, but everything came out ugly, until I had the idea for integrated support.

This is a challenging print, but with a little filing and sanding, the result is worth it.

I have included a "fit testing" file that just has the basic joint. You can use this to test your print settings or practice filing. Trust me, you should print this first, just to make sure!

Scroll further down the page for printing tips!

In hindsight, the design for the scroll join may be more complicated than it needs to be, but I am a former woodworker and like dovetails! The complicated support stand is an absolute must to get a decent print for a filament printer. After all the work, I was happy to get it working and am going to leave it as is.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20-.25mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

You will need supports on both pieces. I used 4 perimeters and 3 tops and bottoms

On the neck piece, make sure there is support generated where the M5 nut is located and also inside the dovetail. You don't need it anywhere else. You don't need a raft for this piece.

On the scroll, use the "full print" model. Also, use supports generated from the build platform only and just under the scroll, you don't need them elsewhere. I have included the support base and scroll as separate models if you need to customize the fit. The full print model has a .25mm separation from support base to scroll. I did my print with the support touching the scroll, but it was very hard to remove, so I left a small gap to ease separation.

You should use a simple 2 layer raft for the scroll as bonding insurance. The scroll print is tall and the printhead can generate enough leverage to knock it over. It is a four hour print for the scroll, so a few minutes extra of insurance won't hurt.

You need to have good support settings and a well-tuned printer. This is print will not tolerate sloppiness.

You will have to do some light filing and sanding to get the right fit. Take off the minimum you need to flatten the mating surfaces.

The dovetail needs some light cleanup filing, but be careful and test the fit as you go. When done right it will be tight to start, but can be press fit by hand, then snap into place. Be careful the dovetail may seem hard to fit, but will get easier once it gets going. If you make it too loose at the entry point it will be very loose by the time it is fully mated.

Also, you will want to test fit the parts on the 12mm rod before assembly, maybe ream out the long hole with a drill bit so you don't have to force anything.

This joint MUST be glued up. You could probably use superglue or epoxy to assemble this. I would caution against superglue so you have some working time.

I used this plastic glue. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JFPF0UQ/ref=od_aui_detailpages00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

It is super thin and melts the PLA. Once dry, the joined PLA is a solid piece. It is nasty stuff, but did a perfect job.

comments.author: conorokane

comments.text: The appearance of the original design was actually due to the desire to make it easy to print and assemble. I tried to keep the number of pieces to a minimum, to have no pieces over 18cm length, and to always have a large, flat surface on every piece for support-free and raft-free printing because this is the best way to ensure consistency over different 3D printers and slicers. I think that when you design within very limiting constraints and at the same time try to produce something functional the end result can turn out to be beautiful, although in a different way to the ornate beauty of a hand-crafted object.

author: cfrueh

description.text: I've been on a quest to find the best way to cool PLA in order to get the best print quality. This is my third, and by far best, fan mount for the MendelMax 2.0 With this fan and mount, I'm getting the best print quality so far. The key was switching from the axial fan that came with the printer (and most other printers) to a blower fan like the one used on the MendelMax 2.0. See the instructions for more details. With this single fan, I'm getting better print quality than I did before with two fans. You can find more about my experiments with cooling fans here: http://trains.socha.com/2014/03/a-better-cooling-fan-for-pla.html

First you'll need a 24V, 50mm blower fan. I purchased mine from here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BKE445C/ref=oh_details_o06_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Use two M4 x 20 screws and nuts to attach the fan to the fan mount. Then use four M3 x 12 screws to attach the air deflector to the mount. Finally, use two M3 x 10 screws and nuts to attach the fan mount to the carriage. The wire on the fan was far too short to reach the printer board, so I cut off the connector and soldered on extension wires long enough to reach the printer board. It's best to use red and black wires as extensions so you can ensure you supply the correct power to the fan.

comments.text: Printing one of these now, got this fan coming in from Amazon tomorrow so hopefully I can give it a try ASAP: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00H8VV0XK/ref=pe_385040_127541850_TE_item

description.text:
If you saw my previous model (The White One) you'll know I was searching for a way to create neater layered shots. My original idea a couple of years ago was to cut a ping pong ball in half, glue it to a straw making a bowl on each end, then drill a hole into the straw at the top, then holes in the straw itself out of the bottom. Pouring the drink in would make it spread out over the bottom ball, and layer above an initial drink.

This is a more refined version of that idea. I like The White One, but you are stuck with just the given height. With this Ezeelayer, you can set the stand at whatever height the drink is at no matter how much is in there before.

Usage : Pour your first drink into the glass. Set the stand at a distance where the platform sits on the top of the drink. Pour in your second drink to layer on top, and carefully remove. To add a third drink, just repeat. Admire your amazing work and then drink it.

Please remember to enjoy my creation responsibly!
(Again my printed model and pictures aren't perfect. This involved a lot of late night fast printing and rushed photography)

title: Universal Spool Holder for Prusa i3 MK2S, yes another one...

description.text:
Lots of these to go around, here's my take.

Features

  • Low friction design (bearings)
  • Compatible with most spools
  • No adjustment needed between different spool widths
  • Rollers for 100 mm and 120 mm maximum spool widths included
  • Curved flange prevents spool from falling off
  • Easy assembly
  • Bearing axles reinforced with metal

Non-printable parts

  • 4x standard 608Z bearings,
  • 4x M3x16 machine screws. Longer ones will work too (they'll stick out inside the rollers), or some wood screws that will roughly fit the holes. You can even go without screws, it'll just not be as strong.

Credits

I've created the models from scratch, but I've been inspired by many other designs, two really nice ones especially: The idea for the wide universal roller comes from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:629381 . The system for fastening the bracket to the printer frame is borrowed from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1832235 . Please consider downloading one of these designs if this one doesn't fit your needs.

See printing notes and post-printing instructions below

Please post a Make if you make this!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200

Infill:

50% cubic, infill threshold 250 *

Notes:

Rollers

Measure the width of you spools and choose model accordingly. Printed in PLA. I used some stick glue as the part is quite high.

Brackets

One of the brackets needs to be a mirror image of the other. Just "Mirror -> Along X-axis" (Slic3r) before slicing the right hand bracket.

Printed in PETG for added strength. Probably PLA would do just fine, but I haven't tested it. If you use PC, Nylon, XT-CF20 or some other strong stuff, you might do without the M3 screws altogether

* I set "Solid infill threshold area" in the slicer (Slic3r in my case) to 250 mm2 for the brackets. This way the support flange and the bearing axles will be solid while the main structure will be infilled.

1. Screw in the four M3 screws into the bearing axles

  2. Push the 608Z bearings into the rollers. This might need some force, and they will be pretty difficult to get back out.

  3. Push the rollers-with-bearings onto the axles of one of the brackets, and then press the other bracket on top.

NOTE: The exact inner diameter of the bearing slots in the rollers or the diameter of the axles might vary due to different print settings. Just sand off some material if the fit is too tight, or add a layer of electrical tape if is too loose.

Optional:
The curve of the flange will have quite visible steps of the layer changes, especially when printed with 200 um. Potentially the spool could snag on these, however this should never occur under normal circumstances, as the roller flanges won't let the spool come near enough, but still. You could either print in higher (or variable) resolution, or you could just sand it down until smooth. See before/after sanding images.

Before sanding After sanding M3 screw in place
Fusion360

description.text:
Original Source under: https://github.com/rmd6502/openscad/blob/master/pinwheel.scad
It's great! Thank you rmd6502.

Endlich ein Windrad für Openscad. Danke.

It's a small script:

sides = 3;
angle = 360 / sides;
radius = 100;
rotate([0, 0, $tangle]) union() {
difference() {
union() {
linear_extrude(10, scale=.525,twist=-22,slices=40) for (rot = [0 : angle : 359])
rotate(rot) translate([0,-1.5,0]) square([radius,3],center=false);
cylinder(h=10,r1=radius/8.5,r2=radius/30,$fn=50);
}
cylinder(h=8,r=2,$fn=20);
difference() {
cylinder(r=radius+.5,h=10,slices=50);
cylinder(r=radius.85,h=10, slices=50);
}
}
// translate([0,0,1.5]) rotate_extrude($fn=90) translate([radius*.85,0,0]) //circle(r=1.5,center=true,$fn=40);
}
//thats all

This is the plug for charging a Xiaomi M365 E-Scooter. I need this plug for a bespoke charger (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2642947). As I couldn't find the right plug anywhere I had to make it. With the things above and two brass parts this becomes an easy task.

You will need some brass rod (diameter 1,5 mm) und brass tube (outer diameter 8 mm and wall thickness 1 mm) as well as some epoxy resin and a soldering iron to finish this part.

If you follow my detailed instructions (http://www.oe1cgs.at/stecker-fuer-xiaomi-m365-e-scooter/, Deutsch, many pictures) you can build this plug in about half an hour.

title: Willys 4x4 punisher accessories and off road add ons

description.text: I love Marty Jaxx jeep and wanted to add my own twist to it. The punisher logo is well bad ass and because I went with 100mm x 39mm tires I needed to make the jeep a little wider so it didn't look so funny. the rear fenders use one of the screw holes for the handle and you have to drill the other two holes after making it level. I have not printed the bumpers yet but I have printed the rear on larger scale it came out perfect. these are designed to slip over his bumpers and you will have to drill holes into the existing bumpers. you will have to trim the corners of the original bumpers to allow it to slide back. I designed to use the M2x8 self tapping screw. I made sure Marty did not have a issue with me uploading the accessories first.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Behold, the holiday card toy pack. As a kid, I always hated greeting cards, because it meant they weren't toys... Now, a kid can have both!. You can choose or give all three of an assembly required ballista, battering ram, or catapult.

Okay, all three of these are separately printable without supports, and all require some assembly (like all the other snap cards on thingiverse) ...

The battering ram and catapult have a " bend" section that should be bent slowly, or have small amounts of heat applied to prevent breakage. Other than that, an appropriately sized rubber band is required for the ballista.

I will upload pics of the build instructions soon, but wanted to get the prints out there for people making holiday cards to send now.

Update:

I have uploaded build videos of all three (yes, including the catapult)

here are the links:

ballista
https://youtu.be/0VyVpfBmqew

battering ram
https://youtu.be/wbWVdR54aEY

and catapult (longer video)
https://youtu.be/RbTI5HV4Njo

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

~25%

Notes:

I had the most success with 20-25 prevent infill on the catapult, the others don't matter too much.

Okay, all three of these are separately printable without supports, and all require some assembly (like all the other snap cards on thingiverse) ...

The battering ram and catapult have a " bend" section that should be bent slowly, or have small amounts of heat applied to prevent breakage. Other than that, an appropriately sized rubber band is required for the ballista. The ballista can only be inserted in the slot AND turned when it is at its thinnest (near the knock)

Further assembly instructions (and more to come)
